Serve Responsive Web

Creating and implementing the responsive redesign of our site was a huge undertaking involving most of the teams in our organization. However once the redesign was in place, front-end development and design efficiency increased significantly. Even though the code base was still large and complex, at least it was just one code base. No more maintaining two code bases, one for mobile and another for desktop.

While we dove in 100% to responsive design from the start, we didn't get it perfect on day one. Our 1.0 delivery was clearly a MVP that we worked hard to make leaner and cleaner over time. Below are some screens of the site's dashboard along with some key discoveries we made on our path from responsive MVP to responsive maturity.

Change Slide

Design Mobile First or How to Add, Not Subtract

If you're going for responsive design, then you should without a doubt also embrace a mobile first attitude and approach to your work. The reason for this is simple: it's easier start from an environment with more constraints (mobile) and build towards an environment with fewer (desktop). You might have to make some hard decisions about what's truly important to the core experience, but I believe that additional focus is actually great for the product.

From a content perspective, you're likely to start with only the core info on the smallest screens and add supporting content as space permits. From a design perspective, starting with a visually simpler design and adding elements is usually far easier than subtracting elements from an initially complex design. Finally from a technical perspective, CSS is terrible at subtraction. In fact, you can't just remove a line of CSS if you don't need it at a certain breakpoint; you have to add an extra line of code to override the first declaration. So since subtracting a style actually means adding a style overwrite, it's just much cleaner to start with the minimum viable CSS to implement the design on mobile and only add or change that base styling to enhance the design as the viewport grows.

Media Query Abstractions are Your New Best Friend

Media Query abstractions are a remarkably easy way to simplify the legibility of your responsive CSS. Using SCSS' native mixin feature, you first give yourself a nicely contained, named list of media queries to be used throughout the code base (the Named Media Queries image above). Then using SCSS' nesting functionality, you nest these mixins under the original style declaration to expand on the base styles across breakpoints (the Splash Photo example above).

You might say "Pat, nesting those media queries will add a lot of unnecessary media query declarations to the stylesheet!". And you would be right. However, you're not going to take a noticeable performance hit for this convenience and I promise that it will save you development time. Not to mention you're less likely to write duplicate styles at different breakpoints if you contain all styles under one declaration. If you really want to make up for the extra lines, go clean up your assets or javascript, both of which will make a bigger impact on performance.

Pair up!

Responsive design has to be a collaborative effort. No current design tool (Adobe, Sketch or otherwise) can give you a 100% accurate mock-up for responsive purposes. They can give you a great starting point for how the site should look and behave at different benchmarks, but ultimately a lot of responsive design needs to happen in the browser. So embrace the back and forth, pair up developer with designer and spend the time getting the experience right together.
